title: Font Book?
content:
Hi all,  
A birthday is coming up for a close friend. He is very into fonts and I would like to explore the possibility of getting a font book of some sort. I’m thinking more coffee-table like (history of fonts) rather than a book about how to use fonts and such.

Are there any such books? A book on Futura would be especially great.

Thanks.  
-Will

comments.content:
Christopher Burke wrote a book about Paul Renner.  
 [http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/1568981589/qid=1138892087/sr=2-1/ref=pd...](http://web.archive.org/web/20070808145714/http:/www.amazon.com/gp/product/1568981589/qid=1138892087/sr=2-1/ref=pd_bbs_b_2_1/103-7091017-1675832?s=books&v=glance&n=283155 "http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/1568981589/qid=1138892087/sr=2-1/ref=pd\_bbs\_b\_2\_1/103-7091017-1675832?s=books&v=glance&n=283155")  
Pieter

I find Burke’s book on Renner very good. There’s quite a bit on Futura, naturally. But I wouldn’t call it “coffe-tableish”.

For a very coofee-tableish book on typography, maybe you want to take a look at [Typography](http://web.archive.org/web/20070808145714/http:/www.amazon.com/gp/product/1579120237/qid=1138896146/sr=2-1/ref=pd_bbs_b_2_1/102-4219255-5238543?s=books&v=glance&n=283155), by Friedrich Friedl, a big enclyclopedia. The information is sometimes incomplete or short, but it has a lot of images...

What I think is also a very nice book is Dutch Type from Jan Middendorp about the Dutch type scene. It’s a little expensive though...  
 [http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/9064504601/qid=1138897330/sr=1-1/ref=sr...](http://web.archive.org/web/20070808145714/http:/www.amazon.com/gp/product/9064504601/qid=1138897330/sr=1-1/ref=sr_1_1/103-7091017-1675832?s=books&v=glance&n=283155 "http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/9064504601/qid=1138897330/sr=1-1/ref=sr\_1\_1/103-7091017-1675832?s=books&v=glance&n=283155")

I second the suggestion of “Dutch Type” by Jan Middendorp. It’s really quite packed with images, biographical info, specimens, and history. Beautifully designed. It is not a typical fluffy coffee-table book, it’s much better.

Something antique might be a good idea.

Perhaps an issue of “The Colophon - a Book Collector’s Quarterly” from the 1930s.  
The whole set, on sale at Oak Knoll for $1500.

They were beautifully printed (and hardcover bound), and each issue used a variety of classic letterpress fonts, on a variety of interesting stocks. fabulous design and illustration. And the articles are fascinating, still.

[Anatomy of a Typeface](http://web.archive.org/web/20070808145714/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Anatomy%252Bof%252Ba%252BTypeface) is a must have for any type lovers collection. I shall third Jan’s [Dutch Type](http://web.archive.org/web/20070808145714/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Dutch%252BType), another essential.

There is also [FontBook](http://web.archive.org/web/20070808145714/http:/typophile.com/wiki/FontBook), the current edition is nearly 8 years old, but if you can wait a couple of months, this massive comprehensive guide to digital typefaces is going back to print and should be available soon.

[Fonts & Logos](http://web.archive.org/web/20070808145714/http:/www.delphipress.com/) by Doyald Young is a coffee table book. It is gorgeous and full of fascinating work if you are a font lover. $75 and worth it.

[Revival of the Fittest: Digital Versions of Classic Typefaces](http://web.archive.org/web/20070808145714/http:/www.amazon.com/gp/product/1883915082/103-7240700-0664657) is a fun coffee table-ready book. I have a copy that I’ve skimmed and am still waiting to read. The layout is quite varied and visually lush.

Thank you all for your wonderful suggestions. Does anyone know of a book about Ernst Friz or Friz Quadrata?

-Will
